title: 108_s667
content: Payment limitations are outlined in Section 1. Section 1001 of the Food Security of 1985 (7 U.S.C. 1308) is amended to set new limitations on marketing loan gains, loan deficiency payments, and commodity certificate transactions. The total amount a person may receive during any crop year is capped at $87,500 for certain gains and payments related to loan commodities. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 sets lower loan rates for loan commodities. Settlement of marketing assistance loans can result in loan deficiency payments or gains from commodity certificates issued by the Commodity Credit Corporation. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 establishes lower loan rates for loan commodities and allows for the settlement of marketing assistance loans through commodity certificates. A provision limits the total amount of payments or gains a person participating in a single farming operation can receive during a crop year. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 sets limits on the total payments or gains an individual or couple can receive in a crop year under certain provisions. Individual limit is $275,000, while a couple's limit is twice the specified amounts. Regulations to ensure compliance must be in place by July 1, 2003. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 imposes limits on total payments and gains for individuals or couples in a crop year. The limits are $275,000 for individuals and twice that amount for couples. Regulations for compliance must be established by July 1, 2003. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 sets limits on payments and gains for individuals or couples in a crop year. The limits are $275,000 for individuals and twice that amount for couples. Regulations for compliance must be established by July 1, 2003. The act also defines criteria for individuals who rent land for a share of the crop below the usual rate or provide custom farming services with compensation at risk. The Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 establishes payment limits for individuals or couples in a crop year. The limits are $275,000 for individuals and twice that amount for couples. Regulations for compliance must be established by July 1, 2003. Criteria are also defined for individuals who provide custom farming services with compensation at risk. The regulations under the Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 establish payment limits for individuals or couples in a crop year, with criteria for custom farming services. The regulations define primary control to include joint operations. The regulations define 'primary control' as a joint operation where one person owns a greater interest than others who participate regularly in management. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue regulations to implement this Act and its amendments without following certain procedural requirements. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted under section 808 of title 5, United States Code.
